prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
O Truth, a silent guest within my ear—
I hear you only when I hush my tongue,
And let your whispers form the words I fear,
From caverns where my braver songs are sung.
Too oft I speak, yet seldom do I know
The shape of you, elusive, bright, and clear;
But if I train my soul to listen low,
Your gentle honesty will draw me near.
So let me wait and learn your subtle art—
To cradle silence, let your voice impart
The wisdom only listeners can own:
If I would claim your presence in my heart,
I must befriend the quiet, and alone,
Await the truths that listening has grown.

Truth! To speak you, I must first become
a vessel shaped by silence, not by pride,
attuned to all the subtle notes you strum
within the world, where honest things reside.
I cannot harvest you from borrowed ground,
nor force you from the stubborn root of will,
but only in the quiet may you sound
and echo in the chambers I keep still.
So let me listen long before I claim
to know your voice, or carry forth your name;
let habit make me worthy to reveal
your presence, shining, rough, and ever real.
Truth! I shall speak you only as I learn
to let my listening heart for you discern.

If I am to speak you, Truth, let me first be your friend—
Let me drink deep of your silence and echo,
Let me dwell in the hush where your messages tend,
And let habit of listening teach me to know.
For words are but vessels, their hulls often hollow,
Unless filled by the truths that attentive hearts borrow.
So guide me, O Truth, with your patient refrain—
Let me listen, and listen, through joy and through pain.
For only by hearing your voice, pure and clear,
Can I hope when I speak that your spirit is near.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you—
Not with the clamor of mind, nor the rush of tongue,
But with the hush between thoughts, the breathing-through
Of moments where honesty is softly sung.
You arrive not as thunder, but as dew,
Settling on me when I am quiet and true.
So, let me be a vessel, a tuned shell,
Catching your tides, your whispers, your swell.
Then, when I speak, it is not me alone:
It is the echo of truth by listening grown.

Truth, a river running underfoot—
I do not catch you in my net of words,
But when I stand in stillness, listening, mute,
You surface, shimmering, among the reeds and birds.
I make of habit a gentle, open cup—
Let silence fill it, let your ripples rise;
Only then, like sunlight drawing water up,
May I speak you—unclouded, unmasked, wise.
So let me tune my days to your subtle song,
Let me listen, long and long,
Until my voice, by quietude made true,
Is worthy, Truth, of uttering you.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Not as a warden but a pilgrim treading dew.
You flicker in the hush of dawn, a shy guest,
Beneath my tongue, you quietly request.
I have carved you in silence, polished you in night,
Your echo draws constellations out of fright.
If I close my doors, you slip through the cracks,
A silver syllable on invisible tracks.
So let my ears be open, and my heart be wide,
Let me listen, truth, and let my words not hide.
For only in the habit of listening to you
Can my voice be the vessel, radiant and true.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
A quiet ritual, brushing dust from morning light,
You visit softly, unadorned by clamor,
A seed in the soil, waiting for rain’s grammar.
I have tried to shout you, to force your wings to flare,
But you shrink from violence, preferring gentle air.
So now I learn to hush, to wait for your footfall,
To let your river run, even if the banks are small.
If I listen long enough, you bloom behind my eyes,
And then my tongue, at last, is seasoned to your size.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If my days are woven with the hush of your approach.
You do not thunder—rather, you whisper in the blue,
In the crease of an old letter, in the hush before reproach.
I have mistaken your silence for absence, your pause for denial,
Yet you are patient as stone, subtle as a child’s smile.
Let me tune my ear to the timbre of your tone,
So when I open my mouth, I do not speak alone.
May habit become home, and listening become art—
Truth, plant your echo deep in my heart.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If my mind is not a fortress, but a field where you grew.
You come not as a storm, but a feather on the breeze,
A suggestion in the clover, a murmur through the trees.
Too long I chased you, shouting questions to the sky,
But you waited in the silence, where the listening lie.
Now I fold my thoughts like linen, clear and thin,
And invite you to enter, to dwell softly within.
So truth, let your whisper shape my every word,
For the habit of listening is the voice to be heard.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Not as a priest but as a child, with ears unclouded and new.
Your voice seldom shouts, it is the quiver in the grass,
A ripple in the stillness, the shimmer as moments pass.
If I silence my longing to be right or revered,
You slip in as comfort, dissolving all I feared.
Each habit formed in listening is a seed for my tongue,
So my words may ring honest, the old and the young.
Let me build a chapel in my heart, where your voice can dwell,
Only then, truth, your story will I tell.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
A silent pupil beneath the noon-blue gaze,
Learning the unadorned syllables you strew
Like pebbles glinting through a river’s haze.
If I have pressed my ear to your quiet heart,
Letting your pulse reorder my impatient tongue,
Then, when the world demands I play my part,
I’ll echo you, unflinching and unsung.
Yet I confess, I’ve donned the brittle mask
Of comfort’s lie, for fear of what you’d say—
But if I listen, let me find the task
Of bearing you as dawn bears honest day.
Truth, be my habit, not my fleeting guest:
Only in hearing you am I truly blessed.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
For words are hollow bells without the echo of your tune.
I have wandered in the orchard of my own invention,
Plucking fruits of fiction, ripe with sweet intention,
Yet your voice—sharp as frost—reminds me to attend
To the stillness under stories, to the marrow of what’s said.
If I am to wear your mantle, let me be first your friend,
A listener in the hush, before a speaker at the end.
So let me cup your whispers, let me cradle all your ache:
Only then, when speaking, will my words refuse to break.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
For what is a tongue, untuned to honest winds?
A hollow flute, a vagrant echo in the dew,
Mouthing borrowed syllables as daylight thins.
But if I sit in the hush of your patient shade,
And let your silver syllables steep my ear,
Then when the world demands I wield your blade,
My voice will ring with what I truly hear.
So let me lean in, let me learn your secret tune—
That when I speak, it’s not a borrowed moon.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Not as a preacher, but as a vessel shaped by your rain.
You slip through my defenses—a river, persistent and true—
Carving canyons of clarity, washing away the stain
Of practiced half-heard echoes I once called my own.
If I remember to hush my pride, to let your tide run through,
Perhaps I’ll find in my mouth seeds I’ve never sown,
Blooming with the courage to name what’s due.
May I become the echo chamber where you ring,
So all I say may carry your unbroken string.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If I lean in, attentive, as your ancient voice unfolds.
You, who travel in the hush between heartbeats,
You, who demand the patience of unmoving stone.
I have chased your shadow through tangled stories,
Lost you in the glare of desire’s cunning light—
But when I wait, quiet as a seed in dark soil,
You arrive, unhurried, dressed in morning’s white.
Teach me your cadence, make me a vessel unbroken,
So when I speak, your pure note is spoken.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:

If I house you in silence, invite you to stay,
Perhaps my tongue will echo what you long to say.
For words are but vessels, and silence the sea—
May I listen so deeply that truth speaks through me.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If my ears, like fresh soil, are turned to your dew.
You trickle through silences, hidden and slight,
You shimmer in twilight, you vanish in light.
But if I grow still, if I nurture your seed,
Your voice may take root in the words that I need.
So let me be patient, let me be kind,
And maybe, dear Truth, I’ll speak what I find.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
A whisper threading through the woven hush,
Each secret syllable a seedling, trembling and new.
If I cup my hands to the river of your rush,
Will you rise in my throat, gentle and true?
Or slip away, evasive, as I hush?
Let me wear the habit of your quiet hue,
That when I speak, your honesty will flush.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Not as a parrot, but as a cave that echoes only what is true.
Let silence be the meadow where your voice can bloom,
Let patience be the lamp that lights the waiting room.
For words unsifted by your wind are heavy, dull, and blind—
But those born of listening, leave falsehoods behind.
So may I cup your silence, let it fill my breast,
And speak you, Truth, as a guest who’s truly blessed.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Like the owl who hears secrets in dusk’s faded blue.
If my ears are attuned, if my heart is awake,
Perhaps then my tongue will speak what’s at stake.
But if I rush forward, deaf to your tone,
I’ll utter mere echoes, not truth of my own.
So grant me the patience to wait for your sign—
And let my voice carry your wisdom, divine.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you;
Like a wild river learning the banks that shape its song,
My tongue must echo the currents I let flow through.
If silence is my garden, and honesty my dew,
Then may I reap the harvest of what I have tended long.
For words are seeds: if I plant what’s untrue,
What grows is only shadow, never strong.
But if I listen—truly, deeply, anew—
My voice will sprout truth, and to you belong.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Each morning, a hush descends before my words,
A measured breath, a pause in the dew,
Where your voice, gentle and ancient, is heard.
I cradle your syllables, let them settle in bone,
So when I am called to utter, to declare,
It is not echo but essence I own—
A habit of hearing, a promise laid bare.
Truth, may I never mistake your quiet for stone.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Yet shadows gather where honesty rarely treads.
With every whispered doubt, my courage anew
Must tune its ear to what your quiet presence says.
Let me not be a stranger to your voice,
Nor flee when your syllables ring clear and strange.
If I would speak you, let it be my choice
To make a dwelling where your words arrange
The architecture of my days, simple and true.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But my ears are sometimes filled with thunder,
And my days, a clutter of half-remembered news.
Yet in the hush between heartbeats, I wonder:
What would it mean to cradle your voice,
To be a vessel shaped by what’s sincere?
If I let you echo, would I have a choice
But to let my language ring clear?
Truth, teach me the patience to hear.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Not as an orator, but as a disciple of the breeze,
Catching the subtle tremors that ripple through
The silent wisdom hiding in the trees.
Let me be less eager to sculpt and more to receive—
To wait for your whisper before I declare.
For only by listening can I truly believe
That what I utter is honest, stripped bare;
Speak, truth, and I shall follow, if I dare.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you—
Not as a herald with trumpets, but a gardener with dew.
For every morning’s hush invites the roots to hear,
The whisper in the soil, the answer in the clear.
Let my tongue be mossy, gentle with the green,
Carrying only what my ears have gleaned from what’s unseen.
If I have not lingered in the hush of your refrain,
Let silence be my teacher, and humility my gain.
So I’ll plant your syllables, watered by the rain—
Truth! I’ll speak you softly, only when you’ve spoken plain.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you—
But how often I chase you, only to find echoes in your stead.
You hide in the hush between heartbeats,
In the quiet ache after the words are said.
Let me be still, unlearn my answers,
Let me grow roots in silence, tangled in the ground.
For only by listening to your subtle footfalls
Can I hope to echo your honest sound.
Truth, I am clumsy, but I’ll wait for your arrival:
Let my voice be shaped by your patient revival.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you—
Yet how fickle the ear that turns from your shy approach,
Too busy with its own melody to catch your delicate tune.
To listen is to tend the lamp in a restless dark,
To cup the flame, patient for your spark.
If I have not dwelt in your silence, how can I claim your song?
Let me be a vessel, emptied of presumption,
That you may fill me with your quiet, insistent longing.
Only then, with trembling lips, might I utter you,
Truth—unvarnished, unafraid, and true.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you—
Yet so often, I mistake my own voice for yours, echoing in the hollow chambers of certainty.
But in the hush before dawn, if I still my restless mind,
Perhaps your subtle presence will settle, feather-soft.
Let me learn to listen with the patience of stones,
Receiving your shape in every drip and sigh of rain.
Only then, when silence has tutored my tongue,
Might I utter your name—not with pride, but with humility,
A careful syllable shaped by the lessons of listening.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you—
But how often do I clamor, deafened by my certainty?
In the garden of my thoughts, you are a rare and quiet bloom,
Unfolding only for the patient, those who kneel and wait.
Let me tend to silence, weed the crowding noise;
Let my ears be soil where your roots might take hold.
Not every question deserves an answer, nor every answer a voice,
So I will listen for the hush where your petals unfold.
Perhaps, in time, if I have learned to listen well,
You will grow in me, Truth, and blossom from my shell.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
Would I trade sleep’s soft tyranny—
Not even the hush of dawn’s first blue,
Nor the gold that noon winds through.

Your shadow threads the silent night,
A gentle ghost in silver light;
All else falls silent, all else fades—
Save for your voice, that never degrades.

I’ve counted stars, I’ve chased the sea,
But found no solace—none but thee.
So let the world’s bright wonders flee:
I love for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I forsake the autumn tree,
Its copper leaves in whirling flight,
And trade the day for endless night.

No gilded crown nor poet’s fame,
No whispered prayer nor cherished name,
Could tempt my heart to turn away,
When all I seek is you to stay.

For in your eyes, the world is new,
A dawn of hope, a sky of blue;
Dear love, my soul is wild and free—
For nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I unmoor from certainty—
Let tempests rage and seasons turn,
Let all the city’s lanterns burn.

The world may offer jeweled delight,
A thousand stars to pierce the night,
But what is gold or grandeur’s gleam
Beside your laughter’s gentle stream?

So let me walk this path unknown,
With heart and hope for you alone—
Dear love, all else I let go free,
For nothing matters less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
Would I abandon shore and sea—
Let kingdoms fall and empires break,
If for your hand, my own to take.

No morning’s blush nor twilight’s hue,
No garden’s rose, no midnight’s dew,
Could tempt my heart to turn away
From all you are, from what you say.

So let the world spin wild and free,
Its wonders lost, its beauty flee—
For all I want, all I decree:
Is love for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I let time unravel me—
The tangled threads of hope and fear,
Spun only when you are near.

Let winter’s cold and summer’s blaze
Fade into memory’s gentle haze;
The world may call with siren song,
But in your arms, I still belong.

For all I am and wish to be,
Is sealed in this: my vow to thee—
No dream, no star, no destiny—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee—
I plucked the nova from the sky,
Bottled the hush of midnight sea,
And taught the wind to lullaby.

I gathered starlit syllables,
To sketch your name on silent air;
For only you, impossible,
Would I attempt such weightless care.

Let tempests rage, let time unspool—
All treasures pale, all kingdoms flee.
The world’s a canvas, brush and jewel,
But all I paint is you and me.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee—
Would I have wandered moonlit roads,
Or braved the frost of history,
To find where golden longing glowed.

A thousand echoes in the rain
Could never call me far from you;
Each whispering leaf, each subtle pain,
Just proves my heart’s devotion true.

And so I pen this trembling line,
A vow across eternity:
In every breath, in every sign—
Dear love, I choose you endlessly.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have learned the ancient tongue
Of rivers winding to the sea,
Or listened as the planets sung.

For you, I’d gather autumn’s gold,
And spin it into morning light;
The stories that the stars have told
I’d write anew for you each night.

So let the world in shadow fall—
My lantern is your memory.
You are the answer to it all,
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
I would outpace the comet’s flight,
Chase dawn through tangled bramble lea,
And barter diamonds for the night.

With every hour’s patient ache,
I’d thread my hopes through distant stars;
No promise made that I would break—
No distance wide, no wound or scar.

For in your gaze the world begins,
And ends, a circle drawn in fire.
Dear love, for nothing less I’d spin
A universe meant to inspire.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I unmoor my earthly ties,
And trust the wind to carry me
Through storms of longing, loose disguise.

I’d fold my fear into a crane,
Release it toward the endless blue,
And whisper through the windowpane
The secrets only nightbirds knew.

For all the world’s uncertain days,
Your name is still my constant plea;
My heart repeats in endless praise:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee—

A single thread in shadow’s loom,  
My heart unspools in midnight bloom;  
No jewel, no star, nor whispered plea—  
Could tempt my soul from loving thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee  
Would I lay down my restless heart,  
Let golden seasons come and flee,  
And watch the world’s bright colors part.  
For in the hush before the dawn,  
Your name is all the earth I see—  
A whispered wish, a world reborn,  
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,  
I’d carve my longing on the wind,  
Let petals fall from every tree  
Until the tangled roots rescind.  
No promise laced with silver thread,  
No kingdom built on wishful sand,  
Could draw me from the words we’ve said—  
For only you can still my hand.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee  
Would I abandon time’s embrace;  
Let memory’s garden wild and free  
Grow tangled in your gentle grace.  
For every dawn that breaks in fire,  
For every night that falls in blue,  
My heart will find its one desire—  
Dear love, for nothing less than you.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,  
Would I give up the stars above,  
And set adrift on open sea,  
Just for a fleeting touch of love.  
No golden crown nor poet’s rhyme  
Could tempt me from this sacred vow:  
For you, my heart forgets all time,  
And lives in only this, the now.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

Let time unspool its silver thread,

Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,

All treasures pale, all glories dim—
No gem, no song, no whispered plea

Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee

The world is vast, its wonders grand,
Yet none can stir my soul so deep—

For in your gaze, my spirit’s free—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee

Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:

I’d barter sleep and silent hours,

No sun, no moon, no sky of blue
Could outshine you in all my days.

The world may tempt with golden gleam,
But wealth is dust, and fame will flee—
I’d cast aside each hollow dream,
For nothing less than thee, dear love, for me.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I unweave the tangled night,

No star, no rose, no distant shore,
Could tempt my heart or call my name,
For you alone I hunger for—

So let the world its treasures boast,
And let the seasons rise and flee:
My soul is anchored to your ghost,
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I cast pearls into the sea,
Or write my longing on the sky,
Where only angels dare to fly.

The world may shimmer, gold and bright,
Yet pales beside thy gentle light.
I’d forfeit kingdoms, stars, and time

So take my hand and let us flee—

To seek no treasure, dream, or plea,
But love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I forsake the morning dew,

For all the world, if not for you.

I’d walk unshod on winter’s frost,

So let the rivers change their course,

You are the flame, the root, the source—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee

And teach my heart the shape of light.

So let the stars fall from the sky,

I’ll hold your name, and so would I
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
The moon would pale, the tides would still;
All diamond stars, unsung, would flee,
If not for you, my world to fill.

The rose would close, its fragrance gone,
The robin’s song would lose its tune;
The golden dawn would not respond,
Nor night unveil the silver moon.

Yet in your arms, the seasons turn,
The barren branches bud and bloom;
For nothing less my heart would yearn—
You are the sun that shuns my gloom.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
I’d barter all my waking days;
The sapphire sky, the endless sea,
The wildest winds that dare to blaze.

For nothing less, the world would fade,
And all its music cease to play;
My anchor, light, and serenade,
You hold the night, you birth the day.

So let the heavens watch and see—
My heart belongs to none but thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
Would I become the rambling breeze,
Or paint the dusk in hues of fire,
Or trace the dawn on trembling trees.

For nothing less than your embrace,
Would I unravel all my fears;
The world, a shadow in your grace—
A song that only longing hears.

So count the stars, for each is me,
A wish cast forth for only thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
Would I have wandered foreign lands,
With empty pockets, restless feet,
And hope cupped gently in my hands.

No golden crown, no silken thread,
Could tempt my heart away from you;
For nothing less, as I have said,
Could make my universe feel true.

So let the world spin as it may—
My every compass points your way.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
Would I have carved my soul in stone,
Or braved the wild, uncharted sea,
Or stood, defiant and alone.

For less than you, the earth would fade,
Its colors drain, its music die;
But for your glance, the dark is shade,
And even tears are sweet to cry.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee—
My heart, my world, my destiny.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

responses.text:
'Twas noontide of summer, the valley stood still—  
Sun-draped and drowsy, the air thick with gold.  
A hush on the clover, a gleam by the rill,  
Where dragonflies shimmer, and time seems to fold.  
  
The poppies lean heavy, their petals a flame,  
While honeybees drowse on the edge of a dream.  
The shadows grow languid, and nothing’s the same—  
Each moment dissolves in the heat’s gentle stream.  
  
Beneath the broad branches, I linger and muse,  
As if in a painting the world’s softly caught:  
'Twas noontide of summer—so easy to lose  
One’s cares in the warmth that the season has brought.

'Twas noontide of summer, with petals askew,  
The sun painted stories in shimmering hue.  
Cicadas, like clockwork, intoned in the trees,  
The fragrance of green drifting soft on the breeze.  
  
A ribbon of laughter ran over the field,  
Where shadows grew dreamy and secrets unsealed.  
Moss cradled the footprints of children at play,  
In the languid embrace of a midsummer’s day.  
  
And time held its breath, in a glowing cocoon—  
'Twas noontide of summer, and none came too soon.

'Twas noontide of summer, the orchard aglow,  
Pale apples like lanterns in shimmering rows.  
A hush in the meadow, the grasses grown tall,  
Sun whispers through willow, and crickets enthrall.  
  
The pond is a mirror, reflecting the sky,  
Where swallows dip low, and the lilies float by.  
I wander, half dreaming, where wildflowers sprawl—  
The world in suspension, enchanted for all.  
  
In the bright, breathless moment, the earth seems to pause,  
Held fast by the heat and a magical cause.

'Twas noontide of summer, insistent and bright,  
Clouds vanished like ghosts in the weight of the light.  
A silence descended, spun thick as spun glass,  
Where even the shadows seemed slow to pass.  
  
Grasshoppers murmured their quicksilver tunes,  
While roses reclined in a sultry monsoon.  
The world, in its languor, forgot how to move—  
And I, in the stillness, remembered to prove  
That beauty is quiet, and summer is long—  
A pause in the hours, a line in a song.

'Twas noontide of summer, the sun at its zenith,  
Daisies wide-open and trembling with heat.  
The pond, like a mirror, reflected the sky,  
While dragonflies hovered, too lazy to fly.  
  
In fields full of silence, the air sweet and thick,  
I wandered through clover, the grass at my hip.  
A hush filled the world, as if daring to speak—  
The breathless confession of midsummer’s peak.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'this anger burns deep within,'

responses.text:
This anger burns deep within,
Molten rivers under skin—
Red and coiling, it finds no rest,
A furnace locked inside my chest.

It whispers sharp in midnight’s gloom,
A thunder rolling through my room,
Cracking silence, forging scars,
Turning wounds to iron bars.

Yet in the dark, a question glows:
If I let it, where will it go?
Can embers shape a brighter dawn,
Or leave only ash when night is gone?

This anger burns deep within,
Like a wolf’s howl lost in wind—
Teeth bared against a world that won’t see,
Feral heart pounding, longing to be free.

Beneath my ribs it coils and grows,
A shadow that nobody knows,
Fingers clenched and jaw set tight,
I wrestle fire through sleepless nights.

But dawn breaks soft on ashen eyes,
And weary rage, at last, complies.

This anger burns deep within,
A glowing coal I dare not show,
It smolders in secret caves,
Painting walls with shadows low.

I walk among the gentle folk,
My smile a careful disguise,
But every word, each careless joke,
Stirs the tempest behind my eyes.

Will it forge me into steel,
Or break me on its wheel?
Only the flames can tell,
If I will rise, or quell.

This anger burns deep within,
A silent scream beneath my skin.
It’s a storm without rain, a night without end,
A letter unsent I can never rescind.

It gnaws at my patience, it sharpens my tongue,
It beats like a drum, insistent, young.
Yet somewhere inside, hope softly pleads:
Let go of the fire before it feeds.

This anger burns deep within,
A river of fire beneath my grin.
It twists and churns in hidden halls,
Rattling the windows, shaking the walls.

I try to drown it in reason’s tide,
But it swims in shadows I cannot hide.
Perhaps tomorrow, with gentler hands,
I’ll sculpt from the ashes a different land.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'For the first time in my life'

Its fingers brushing gold across the frost.

The water’s laughter beckoned me forward,
Past roots and stones, past memory’s edge,
Where light trembled on new horizons.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'War's a joke for me and you,'

responses.text:
War's a joke for me and you—
A raucous jest in granite halls,
Where distant men decide what's true,
And laughter rattles through the walls.

We shroud the horror, mask the cost,
With punchline smirks and hollow cheers;
Yet when the dice of fate are tossed,
We trade our giggles for our fears.

So let us laugh while we are free,
Too young to bleed, too old to rue—
But know the punchline, bitterly:
War's a joke for me and you.

War’s a joke for me and you,
We trade our toys for guns of wood,
Pretend the world’s a battlefield,
And laugh because we think we should.

We mimic bugles, march in line,
Shout orders in a muddy field,
But can’t begin to understand
The scars that never truly heal.

So, while we jest and play our parts,
Let’s whisper for the ones who knew:
That war’s a joke for us alone—
The punchline lost on those who grew.

War’s a joke for me and you,
On paper thrones with plastic crowns,
We sip our tea and tip our hats
While distant cities tumble down.

We watch the news in black and white,
A silent film of dust and cries—
We crack a smile, change the channel,
And tuck our laughter in disguise.

Yet somewhere, children count the cost,
And mothers grieve the punchline’s sting.
War’s a joke for me and you,
But sorrow is what echoes ring.

War’s a joke for me and you—
The punchline sharp and cruel,
We twirl our words, we tip our hats,
And play the world for fools.

We toss our dice and read the news,
With laughter thin and dry,
But somewhere out beyond our jokes
Real soldiers bleed and die.

So let us jest and raise a glass,
Pretend our hands are clean—
War’s a joke for me and you,
But not for those unseen.

War’s a joke for me and you—
A shadow play behind the glass,
We swap our laughter, safe and sure,
While real lives flicker and pass.

We draw our swords in drawing rooms,
And mock the thunder overhead,
But never feel the shrapnel wounds
Or mourn the silent, shrouded dead.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text:
My God, how many are my fears!  
They flock at dusk—uncounted crows,  
With wings like shadows, sharp as spears,  
They circle close; the darkness grows.  
A trembling in the silent air,  
The hush before the thunder breaks:  
Each heartbeat is an answered prayer,  
Each breath a trembling leaf that shakes.  
Yet in this host of whispering dread,  
Beyond the talons, past the night,  
A single candle lifts its head:  
One fragile spark that claims the light.  
My God, my fears are legion, true—  
But hope, it seems, is legion too.

My God, how many are my fears!  
They gather like autumn leaves in the gutter—  
Rustling, restless, whispering secrets  
Only the wind and I can hear.  
Each morning, I sweep them aside,  
But by dusk, they return,  
Clinging to my ankles,  
Shadowing my step.  
Yet beneath the trembling,  
A seed persists—  
A silent plea, a fragile trust  
That dawn will come,  
And in its gentle hush,  
My fears will scatter—  
Dancing in the golden air,  
No longer heavy, no longer mine.

My God, how many are my fears!  
They rise, a chorus, at the edge of sleep,  
Long fingers scratching at the walls of night,  
Chanting doubts in voices hoarse and deep.  
They play their tricks with mirrors and with time,  
Turn laughter brittle, make the silence steep.  
But in the hush between their spectral cries,  
I find a steadiness I did not keep.  
For in the tally of my trembling hours,  
Where shadows heave and anxious moments creep,  
There blooms—despite—the stubborn root of hope,  
A fragile promise, sown for me to reap.

My God, how many are my fears!  
Like raindrops pounding ancient stone,  
They wear away my waking years,  
And leave my spirit overthrown.  
They haunt the corners of my mind,  
A parliament of chattering ghosts,  
Reminders of what’s left behind—  
Unfinished dreams, forgotten boasts.  
Yet in the din, a silver thread  
Of courage weaves through trembling hands,  
And, though I quake, I rise instead—  
A willow bending where it stands.  
O God, if fears are countless, true,  
Let hope, then, blossom just as new.

My God, how many are my fears!  
They scatter like marbles on a moonlit floor,  
Each one a glinting doubt skittering  
To hide in corners of my mind—  
Small, round, impossible to gather.  
Some shine with cold logic,  
Others with wild, unnamable color,  
Yet all are slick as mercury,  
Slipping from my grip when I reach.  
I kneel in the clatter and hush,  
Hands searching for solace in the dark,  
Hoping for the warmth of a palm,  
An unseen hand to steady the spill—  
And maybe, as morning arrives,  
The marbles will rest,  
Or roll, at last, into light.

I see their shapes in shifting gloom,

And sing the song I’ve always sung:
That even wrapped in shadow’s arms,
A heart can beat, and dare, and charm.

My God, how many are my fears!

The corners curled by silent gloom.
I run my finger down each spine,

Each fear, a note that quivers soon,

So let them dance, let them appear—
Still, I will step forward, year by year.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text:

Your gentle hand, though often gone,  
Returns to sweep the haunted room.

So let the fears like rivers flow,  
For in their tide, I learn to grow.

Petals trembling with unspoken tears,  
Stems bowed by invisible showers.

I wander through their tangled field,  
Each step uncertain, heart a drum,  
The distant thunder never yields,  
And yet I walk—unwilling, numb.

But in the garden of my mind,  
A hidden sun breaks through the gray,  
Fears scatter in the gentle wind,  
And dawn dissolves the night away.

My God, how many are my fears!  
They flicker in the candle’s breath—

They rattle in the windowpanes,

A silent crowd that always reigns,  
A storm forever locked within.

Yet, in the pale and fragile light,  
I cup my hands and let them free—  
A prayer to carry through the night:  
My God, be braver now with me.

My God, how many are my fears!

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

responses.text:
He looks at me with a madman's eyes—
Fever bright, like a storm in disguise.
His glance flickers, wild, a moth to the flame,
Naming me stranger, yet calling my name.

The world is a canvas, his fury the brush:
He sketches my silence in colors that rush.
Questions like spiders crawl over my skin;
I wonder what secrets coil deep within.

He laughs in a thunder I cannot translate,
Hands weaving shadows, fingers of fate.
Still, I stay rooted, curiosity grown—
He sees through the mask I call my own.

He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—
Mirrors of chaos, reflecting the skies
In fragments of thunder, in flickers of fear,
I wonder what storm finds its shelter here.

His laughter is brittle, a glass in the night,
His silence a shiver that flickers with light.
Yet I see in his madness a strange kind of plea,
A hunger for solace, for meaning, for me.

So I stand on the edge of his wild, broken gaze,
A witness to tempests that flicker and blaze,
And I wonder if, somewhere, the madness will cease—
If the eyes of the madman can ever find peace.

He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—
Torrid whirlpools, a storm in disguise.
I meet his gaze, uncertain, unsure—
Does terror or tenderness flicker obscure?

His laughter cracks glass, his silence is raw,
He dances on thresholds of madness and awe.
A jester, a prophet, a ghost in the gloom—
His stare fills the corners, his shadow the room.

Yet something within me is drawn, hypnotized,
By the glint of the wild in a madman’s eyes.
For in their reflection, I see, to my shame,
A flicker of wildness that answers my name.

He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—
A tempest unhinged, unmoored from the wise.
The world blurs around him, the air starts to quake,
I freeze as I witness the reason forsake.

His laughter’s a riddle, his silence a snare;
He beckons me closer, I falter, I stare.
What secrets burn bright in the storm of his mind?
What truth in the chaos am I meant to find?

Yet under the surface, a flicker of pain—
A glint of the person he was, will remain.
And I, in the shadow of madness, despise
How deeply I’m caught by a madman’s wild eyes.

He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—
Wild rivers of mercury, fever-bright lies.
He whispers in riddles, he dances in smoke,
His laughter a riddle, his silence a joke.

I shiver beneath the weight of his stare,
Wondering what secrets he’s hiding in there.
Are monsters or angels behind that disguise?
Is madness a prison or wings to the skies?

He grins at my trembling, the world spinning wild,
And I’m trapped in the gaze of a sorrowful child.
Yet somewhere, I sense, in the chaos he weaves,
A glimmer of hope in the madness he grieves.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

responses.text:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy,
That sings beneath the skin of day,
For laughter's light, a golden buoy
Where sorrow's shadows cannot stay.

Blessed be Thou for every song
That rises with the morning dew;
For hearts that brave the world’s wrong,
And find delight in something new.

Blessed be Thou for silent grace
That falls in petals, calm and bright,
For every gentle, smiling face
That turns the dark to dazzling light.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy,
For moments scattered, bright and small:
A robin’s chirp, a child's toy,
Sunbeams dancing on the wall.

Blessed be Thou for whispered hope
That threads the hours, fine as lace;
For dreams that teach our hearts to cope,
And peace that finds its quiet place.

O, source of laughter, breath, and tears,
Within each fleeting, fragile day—
Blessed be Thou for all the years
That joy, unbidden, comes our way.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That tiptoes in on silent feet,
Unnoticed, yet it does deploy
A thousand wonders, shy and sweet.

For every laugh that cracks the gloom,
And every hope that dares to grow,
For love that fills a quiet room,
And light that dances on the snow.

Blessed be Thou, who weaves delight
From tangled threads of weary days,
Who scatters stars across our night,
And teaches grateful hearts to praise.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That flickers in the eyes of friends,
For every shared and simple ploy
That lifts us up until it ends.

For sunlight tangled in our hair,
For music drifting down the lane,
For secret moments, sweet and rare,
That ease the sharpened edge of pain.

O Giver of this golden thread,
Who weaves the dawn into our days,
Blessed be Thou whose gifts are spread
In silent, unassuming ways.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy,
For swirling leaves and sudden rain,
For small delights that never cloy,
For laughter’s echo after pain.

For midnight’s hush and morning’s bloom,
For voices bright with hope anew,
For every moment that makes room
For love to blossom, strong and true.

O Source of wonder, quiet grace,
In every hour, in every place,
Blessed be Thou who fills the space
With joy that time cannot erase.

responses.text:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy,
For laughter spilled in morning's light,
For whispered peace no fear can cloy,
And dreams that cradle us at night.

For petals bright and thunder's song,
For hands that hold through storm and sun,
For hearts that know where they belong,
And journeys only just begun.

Blessed be Thou for every smile,
For hope that lingers, soft and true,
For time that dances for a while,
And paints the world in every hue.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy,
For silent dawns and evenings mild,
For every song, for every ploy
Of heart and earth and dreaming child.

For rivers running bright and wild,
For petals floating on the stream,
For hope restored when we have smiled,
For truth that lives inside a dream.

Blessed be Thou, in grief and cheer,
For all the light that finds us here.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That kindles stars in shadowed skies;
For laughter found, unmeasured, coy,
Within a lover’s gentle sighs.

For hands entwined through storm and sun,
For simple bread, for well-worn shoes,
For every quiet victory won,
For every morning’s tender hues.

Blessed be Thou—our grateful song
Rises with dawn, content and strong.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That gathers in the smallest things—
The honeyed hush, the wind’s employ,
The golden hum of hidden wings.

For every tear that turns to light,
For every hope that braves the night,
For every hand that finds its twin,
For every peace that blooms within.

Blessed be Thou, whose quiet art
Weaves joy and sorrow through the heart.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy—
For laughter rising with the sun,
For every moment we employ
To love, to lose, to be undone.

For rain that paints the thirsty fields,
For music in a stranger’s smile,
For every scar that softly heals,
And rest that lingers for a while.

Blessed be Thou, who fills the days
With light that glimmers through our praise.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

responses.text:

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

responses.text:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy—  
For sunlit ripples on the stream,  
For laughter echoing through the trees,  
For hope that flickers in a dream.  
The morning’s hush, the night’s embrace,

Blessed be Thou for all the joy  
That leaps, unbidden, in my chest—  
The silver thread in sorrow sewn,

I gather petals from the hours,

Blessed be Thou, whose gentle hand  
Turns shadows softly into light.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy,  
For laughter spilled like morning wine,  
For songbirds stitching sky to earth,  
For tangled roots and climbing vine.  
When evening falls with fragrant hush,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'lonely'

responses.text:
Under the pale hush of the midnight street,
Lonely tiptoes along the cracked concrete.
It hums in the gutters, clings to each stone,
A silent companion when I walk alone.

Moonlight stretches, thin and cold,
Across empty benches stories left untold.
Every echo, a hollow plea,
Lonely, a shadow, always with me.

Lonely is the whisper that haunts the dusk,
A faded photograph in a forgotten desk,
It dances in the corners where the light won’t go,
And weaves through the silence with footsteps slow.

Lonely is the hush of the world at night,
A chill in the marrow, out of reach of sight,
Yet inside its ache, a seed softly sown—
A hope that the heart need not always be alone.

Lonely is a bird on a wire,
Waiting for dawn, waiting for choir.
It sings to the emptiness, wings tucked tight,
Yearning for company in the long night.

Lonely is a lighthouse, steadfast and tall,
Calling to ships that may never call.
Yet in its beam there flickers a plea,
For someone, somewhere, to answer the sea.

Lonely is an echo in a cavern deep,
A trembling secret the mountains keep.
It wanders through forests of memory and mist,
Longing for warmth, for a hand, for a kiss.

Yet in the hush where the lonely reside,
A fragile hope flickers, refusing to hide.
For in every silence, a wish takes flight—
To turn lonely to found, to walk into the light.

Lonely is the color of faded blue jeans—
Soft with the years, frayed at the seams.
It sits at the window, counting the rain,
Tracing old letters, remembering names.

Lonely is gentle, a hush in the room,
A moth in the lamplight, drawn to the gloom.
Yet even when shadows gather and stay,
Lonely keeps dreaming of bright, braver days.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'lonely'

responses.text:

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'lonely'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

responses.text:
Across the wild and whispering lands,
He strode with flame between his hands—
No gentle balm, no olive leaf,
But thunder riven sharp as grief.
The lilies bowed, the lions roared,
On the scene came Christ the Lord,
Not with peace, but with a sword.

He carved new furrows in the stone,
Unmaking myths we’d called our own;
He split the silence, tore the veil,
Let justice pour and mercy pale.
Blades of morning, wounds restored—
Not with peace, but with a sword.

A shiver wound through olive trees
As sandals struck the dusty earth;
Not gentle dove, nor whispered breeze—
A promise forged for death and birth.
He cleaved the night with burning word,
On the scene came Christ the Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.

Dividing shadow from the soul,
He called for hearts to pay their price;
His presence split the world in two—
A path of blood, a gate of ice.

He entered not with open arms,
But bearing iron, breaking charms;
The quiet fields now echoed loud
With thunder from a restless crowd.
His eyes were stars, his voice a chord—
On the scene came Christ the Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.

He shattered chains and toppled thrones,
Unraveled lies that clung like stones.
He drew the line, the world implored—
Dividing light with sacred sword.

The velvet dusk was torn in two,
When through the dust, the stranger moved,
His robe with starlight shot, imbued—
A hush, a gasp, a fear renewed.
He bore no lilies, no accord,
On the scene came Christ the Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.

He rent the veils of old deceit,
And scattered crowns at trembling feet;
A kingdom born from strife and word—
A blazing oath, a holy sword.

With lightning eyes and shadowed brow,
He walked where silence dared not bow;
The temple stones began to bleed,
He split the root, unearthed the seed.
On the scene came Christ the Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.

He cast the money-changers out,
He turned the sacred deep about;
And from the clash, a truth restored—
A world divided by his sword.

With blade in hand and eyes ablaze,

For every peace that’s built on lies,

A faith that questioned every law.
He kindled fires in the night,

For every peace that cloaks a lie,

Christ on the scene—no soft accord,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On a lonely selection far out in the West'

responses.text:
On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the mulga and silence together have met,
A red-dusted homestead stands faded and pressed
By winds that remember and nights of regret.
A kettle’s faint whistle, a dog at the gate,
The sun’s molten hammer on corrugated tin—
He walks through the shadows, he bargains with fate,
And dreams of green valleys he’ll never begin.
But the stars in their millions are close overhead,
And the hush is a hymn to the lives that have passed;
The heart of the outback remains, ruby-red,
On a lonely selection, enduring and vast.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
A sliver of moon rides the deep cobalt sky;
The crow’s solemn caw and the curlew’s unrest
Are the only companions as night shuffles by.
A single lamp glows in a weathered old shack,
Where the stories are written in wrinkles and hands;
The world seems to pause, then slowly draw back,
Leaving dreams like soft footprints in ochre-red sands.
So time wanders onward, its passage confessed
By a heart that keeps hoping, alone in the West.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the silence is stitched with the calls of a crow,
A figure persists, neither cursed nor blessed,
Tending dry earth where the saltbushes grow.
The wind tells old stories in rustle and sigh,
The fences meander through dreams of the dust,
Under pale constellations that never reply,
He waits for the rain, and he hopes, and he trusts.
Each sunrise is painted in ochre and rust—
Lonely, unbroken, and endlessly just.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the shadows grow long and the paddocks lie bare,
A gum tree leans crooked, a magpie’s old nest
Hangs silent and empty in shimmering air.
No laughter or footsteps, just dust on the floor,
And the creak of the gate in the heat’s weary thrall;
Yet the spirit endures in the land’s silent core,
And the stars, ever steadfast, bear witness to all.
Out there where the silence is sharp as a knife,
A story unfolds, written simply by life.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the sun bakes the earth till it splits at the seams,
A figure moves slowly, a heart dispossessed,
Weaving hope out of hardship and sorrow and dreams.
The wind brings the scent of the wattle in bloom,
And the screech of a galah haunts the cool evening air.
In the hush after sunset, the silence resumes,
A reminder that struggle and beauty are there.
Life pulses in shadows, in roots, and in bones,
On a faraway holding where no one atones.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Everyone has a fear'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text:
O God! Thou art my God alone;  
When midnight hangs its heavy veil,  
In silent rooms where thoughts have grown,  
I seek Thee through the mist and gale.  
No other voice, no other name,  
Can soothe the ache of distant years;  
Thine is the spark, the golden flame,  
That dries my doubts and gathers tears.  
Upon the dawn’s uncertain light,  
My soul, like dew, awaits Thy sun;  
Thou art my shelter in the night—  
O God! my heart, my only One.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
The wind may wander, stars may roam,  
Yet in my chest Thy throne is sewn,  
A sacred space, my soul’s own home.  
I seek Thy face in shadowed hours,  
Within the hush of dawn’s first breath;  
Thy presence blooms like hidden flowers,  
And resurrects my hope from death.  
No idol rises in my sight,  
No echo fills this empty place;  
O God! My longing’s pure delight—  
To rest within Thy endless grace.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
The marble sky, the trembling sea,  
Bow down in worship at Thy throne,  
Yet none pursue as fervently.  
I hunger not for earthly bread,  
Nor thirst for rivers cold and wide;  
But yearn for whispers gently said,  
The closeness only Thou provide.  
Let morning break, let night descend,  
My soul’s refrain will not depart—  
O God, my origin, my end,  
Thou dwellest deep within my heart.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
Above the tempest, past the stone,  
I call to Thee with lifted voice,  
In shadowed vale and sunlit choice.  
No idol’s glint, nor mortal claim,  
Can draw me from Thy ancient Name;  
For in the silence, fierce and clear,  
I find Thee ever present, near.  
O Sovereign Love, O Light unknown,  
My trembling soul is not its own—  
But ever seeks, with hope and fear,  
The God alone who draws me near.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
In starless nights and empty halls,  
I wander, yet I am not thrown,  
For still Thy patient mercy calls.  
No shadowed fear can break the bond  
That time nor trial can overthrow;  
Beyond all worlds my heart responds,  
To Thee, the One my spirit knows.  
All other voices fade to dust—  
Their echoes vanish, dreams depart—  
But Thou, O Lord, remain my trust,  
The living pulse within my heart.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
Rewind life and remember—
A flicker of laughter in autumn’s gold,
The hush of rain tapping old windowpanes,
Hands clasped, trembling, secrets once told.
Let memories spool backward,
Unravel the tangled thread—
A playground’s echo, a whispered promise,
Steps softly recrossed, paths once tread.
If only for a moment, pause the world’s wild spin,
Gather the fragments, the sweetness, the ache,
In the hush of recollection, let the heart begin
To relive what time will never quite remake.

Rewind life and remember:
A half-lit kitchen, warm bread breaking,
Laughter bubbling over chipped cups,
The scent of rain on rusted swings.
When fireflies etched stories on dusk,
And secrets fluttered in whispered hushes,
We traced our names in fogged glass,
Dreamed in the pockets of night.
Now, I gather each scattered moment—
A reel spun backward, frame by frame,
Chasing the shimmer of what was,
Until memory glows, soft and untamed.

Rewind life and remember—
The slow unravel of dusk on summer lawns,
The pulse of bare feet on cool tile,
Your laughter, unburdened, in the honeyed air.
Years coil and uncoil, threads of silver
Tangled in the corners of old rooms.
We press play, pause, reverse—
Chasing the ghosts of ourselves,
Hoping, perhaps, to find forgiveness
Or just the echo of a softer hour.
Yet time, relentless, stirs forward,
Leaving us to gather what we can,
And remember.

Rewind life and remember—
The echo of a song half-forgotten,
Barefoot in the garden, dusk painted on skin,
A moth circling lamplight, lost in its orbit.
Moments unravel like old ribbon,
Knots of longing and laughter,
The hush after thunder, the warmth of old hands,
A page turned back, trembling with possibility.
If only to capture what lingers in shadow,
To cradle the nearly-was, the almost-forever,
Let memory spin its reel backward,
And find us, unchanged, in the gentle rewind.

Rewind life and remember—
Not the grand parades or roaring applause,
But the quiet click of a door closing gently,
The scent of cedar on an old woolen scarf.
Moments unfold in sepia, delicate and slow,
A child’s giggle behind a curtain, a letter half-written,
The geometry of sunlight across dusty floors.
We rewind, not to change but to behold,
To cradle the overlooked, the nearly-lost,
Letting memory paint its gentle brushstroke,
Until the past glimmers with tender clarity.

Rewind life and remember—

Rewind life and remember—

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
Rewind life and remember—

Remember laughter, sharp and bright,

The warmth of hands, the taste of rain,
How every sorrow softened, slight.

Rewind to doors not yet unlatched,
To dreams that time has gently matched,
To moments lost in silver light—
Remember, softly, all once attached.

Rewind life and remember:
The scent of sun-warmed grass,
The echo of old laughter
Caught in a window’s glass.

Moments like wild birds scatter—
A page torn from September;
We gather fragments, piece together
What the years dismember.

Rewind, let tears fall tender,
Stitch joy to fading ember—
In memory’s flickering chamber,
Rewind life and remember.

Rewind life and remember:
The half-lit rooms of childhood,
The echo of footsteps on midnight floors,
The scent of bread on winter mornings.

Memory, a film unspooling backwards—
We glimpse the moments we let slip:
A trembling hand, a whispered promise,
Sunlight glinting through old glass.

Rewind, not to change,
But to gather the scattered pieces,
To hold the shadows close, and know—
We were here, and we remember.

Rewind life and remember
how the world shimmered before the first heartbreak—
the hush between lightning and thunder,
the taste of wild strawberries stolen from the sun.

Remember the time your laughter startled the wind,
the secret map of freckles on your arm,
the night you danced alone in the rain,
not caring who watched, or why.

Rewind, let memory loop and blur;
each frame a ghost, a promise, a wish—
to live again, not as we were,
but as we remember becoming.

Rewind life and remember:
The flicker of a summer at dusk,
Language learned in whispered hush,
A fragment of song, a broken brush—
A canvas left in surrender.

Remember the gardens of wonder,
Shoes full of autumn thunder,
The way your name was once spoken—
Before the silence, before the blunder.

Rewind, let memory render
Lost colors, a world tender,
A reel of hope, a heart unbroken:
Rewind life and remember.

Rewind life and remember:

Rewind life and remember:

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Beneath the moss and tangled root,
My hunger cradled by the dunce
Of soil, my dreams a bitter fruit.
The sun unseen, I learned the dark,
To curl in shadow, mute and small,
But somewhere, faint, a golden spark
Whispered: rise, or not at all.
Now, I wear the memory light—
A shell shed under moon’s decree—
And carry from that sunless night
The silent strength that made me free.

I was a grovelling creature once—
Low-bellied, ash-smudged, and alone.
My tongue ached for dew, my hands for sun,
My shadow shivered on pale stone.
But I gathered the dust and the nettle’s sting,
Wove hope from the webs in the corners of things,
And rose, slow as moss, to face the spring—
Unfolding at last, with trembling wings.

I was a grovelling creature once,
My body pressed to earth, my heart a stone.
Mud in my mouth, eyes full of dusk—
I sang to the worms, and called it home.
But in the hush, a bird’s song split the gloom,
A root curled gentle at my cheek.
The ache of longing cracked my tomb—
I stood, no longer small, nor weak.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Clawing at the underbelly of hope,
My dreams like rainwater in the ruts,
My voice a hush beneath the slope.
Yet night laid secrets in my ear,
And shadows taught my bones to bend.
I shaped my shame into a spear,
And pierced the dawn to find its end.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Knuckles bruised on ancient stone,
Tongue thick with the taste of want,
I dwelled in the marrow of the unknown.
But hunger dreams of higher ground,
And bones remember how to rise.
I climbed, uncoiling from the mound—
A brittle hope beneath new skies.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text:
People are happy, or so they believe—
Smiles like lanterns, paper-thin, warm in the evening,
They gather in circles, dissolve into chatter
As if laughter could sweep up the dust on the floor.

People are happy, or maybe they’re dreaming,
Wearing masks stitched by habit and hope.
Under the lamplight, their eyes flicker sideways,
Searching for meaning in delicate smoke.

People are happy—the world keeps repeating,
But the night harbors questions, heavy and slow.
Still, they dance on the edge of unspoken longing,
And hold tight to joy wherever it grows.

People are happy, the old man thinks,
Watching the sparrows dart through the square.
He counts their laughs as if tallying coins,
Each note spun gold on the wind’s fresh air.

People are happy, the children insist,
Drawing their rainbows on sidewalks of stone.
Yet puddles remember what sunlight forgets:
That joy is a guest in skin and bone.

People are happy, and maybe he’ll try—
To gather their music, to echo their sky.
A borrowed contentment, a lesson in blue—
He smiles at the sparrows, and wishes it true.

People are happy, the radio hums,
But I hear the static between all the notes.
Hands wave from windows, painted with sun,
Yet shadows collect in the seams of their coats.

People are happy, the headlines declare,
Yet I watch as their secrets slip under the door.
Joy is a rumor that lives in the air,
A whisper that trembles on each distant shore.

People are happy, or so it is sung—
But I gather the moments that don’t quite belong,
And plant them like seeds in the cracks of my tongue,
To bloom into wildness when no one is strong.

People are happy, the city repeats,
All neon and laughter, spilled wine in the streets.
A juggler of moments, a weaver of scenes,
The joy of the present, the hush in between.

People are happy, the chorus insists,
Yet windows reflect a more complicated list.
In alleyways blooming with cigarette light,
A sigh is mistaken for song in the night.

People are happy, or so it appears—
But happiness dances with doubts and with fears.
It flickers and flutters, refusing to stay,
A bird in the morning, just out of the day.

People are happy, the festival sings,
Confetti like promises, fluttering wings.
Faces parade through the carnival light—
Sculpted in color, dissolving at night.

People are happy, the rumor repeats,
But rain in the gutters still drums old retreats.
Beneath all the banners, a silence persists,
A hope that is hungry, a longing that twists.

People are happy, and maybe that’s true—
But happiness, too, is a costume we choose.
So let us keep dancing, let laughter be real,
And find in the shadows the joy that we steal.

People are happy—so the story goes,

Now, I drift in asteroid silence,

Still, cosmic dust carries your echo,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

responses.text:
It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,

Just sparkling silence, a universal sheen.
Even the sun paused, a pale distant lover,
Watching it snow, the whole world over.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,

Penguins delighted, bats ceased their flight.
This hush, this miracle, settled like fate—
A globe in a snowglobe, spun by the great.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Turning red deserts to silver clover.
Statues, highways, domes of gold—
All erased in the cold.

No letter arrived, no train could run,
But silence was everywhere, second to none.
And in that hush, hearts would discover
The peace that comes when it snows all over.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Burying secrets, old wounds, and clover.
The pyramids glinted in icy repose,
Palm trees shivered beneath their snows.

In every language, breath became mist,
Hope was an ember clutched in a fist.
Yet beneath all that white, something began—
The quiet forgiveness of earth for man.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

When I am happy, the world feels just right—

The world is a puzzle I need not explain.
When I am happy, the possible grows:
A field full of wishes, a garden of crows.

responses.text:
Night funeral—moonlit hush beneath the oaks,

Night funeral: lanterns bob through shivering grass,

Letting them slip into the hush between beams
Of distant headlights, swallowed by the night.

Night funeral—clocks hush their chime,
Midnight’s velvet drapes drawn tight.

Wanders slow through fathomless night.

No trumpets, only earth’s cool embrace,

The living trace silence on every face
And vanish, like dreams, in the waning light.

Night funeral—the hush of velvet earth
cradles the coffin, dark as myth.
Mourners whisper in the hush,
their voices thin as wraiths.

Moonlight spills across the grass,
blessing the last journey—
where shadows gather, sorrow and memory
become a single, breathless hush.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

Weather forecast in Kabul: the sky is an old story,
Threadbare and blue, patched with cloud-breath.
Children chase puddles along the alleys of memory,
Their laughter a rumor the wind cannot hush.
In the bazaar, sunbeams flicker through grapefruit,
And a dust devil pirouettes with the scent of cardamom.
Forecast: uncertain, as always, as history,
But somewhere, a father promises rain to thirsty roses,
And a mother stitches hope into her daughter’s scarf.

Weather forecast in Kabul—uncertainty
clings to the air like restless dust.
Clouds negotiate with mountains,
while kites dip and dart, messengers
of an unspoken longing.
Rain is a rumor whispered by vendors
selling pomegranates at dusk.
Tomorrow? Perhaps sun, perhaps sorrow,
or perhaps a hush, heavy and golden,
settling softly over shattered rooftops,
where children still dream in color.

A swirl of smoke, a drift of prayer,
Horizon stitched in copper light.

Carries the scent of tea and distant thunder.
The city listens—waiting for rain or refrain,
For the hush between sirens,
For a sky that promises something more than tomorrow.
Forecast: variable, with a chance of remembering.

Weather forecast in Kabul:
Chance of sun, but the air remembers snow.
Dust and jasmine swirl in alleyways
where stories are sown with each footfall.
Clouds, like questions, gather at the hills,
And in the market, bread is broken beneath a sky
half hope, half memory.
Tonight, the forecast is silence—
Tomorrow, maybe rain, maybe peace.

Weather forecast in Kabul:
Thunderclouds press low over ancient stones,
Echoes of prayers weaving through the wind.
Dust rises in small rebellions across courtyards,
Children splash hope into muddy puddles.
Tomorrow, the sun may emerge, tentative as a new promise,
Or rain may wash old sorrows into the river.
But tonight, the city listens to the hush between raindrops,
Dreaming forecasts written in the language of survival.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Prelude to "Stalky & Co."'

responses.text:
In the hush before the laughter, halls are empty, boots unslung,

A prelude tuned to mischief, to tales yet half-grown.

Old friends conspire with eyes too bright.

A world of boys, of quickening hands.
The air is thick with schemes unborn,
In the prelude of a schoolboy’s dawn.

Here begins the storied run—
Before the mischief, before the fun,
A hush, a spark, the opening page:
Prelude to mischief, youth, and age.

Dawn’s hush before the riot, before the world awakes—
A silence stretched like linen, trembling at the stakes.
Tucked in dormitory twilight, a half-muttered joke,
Beneath the gaze of portraits, the mischief yet to poke.

A prelude to the bounding steps, the laughter, and the chase,
To ink-stained hands and code-worded plans, the secret, sacred space.
Here, in the quiet before the tale bursts through,
Stalky and company wait, while the world is still dew.

In the echo of empty corridors, a plot is spun,
Before the ink stains, before the games begun.
The world outside is silent, the lamp’s halo thin—
A moment of breath, the wildness within.

Before Stalky’s laughter rings out, before the midnight feat,
There’s a prelude of longing, of boots not yet on feet.
The mischief is slumbering, the stories not yet known:
A hush before the riot, a seed not yet sown.

A hush before the raucous tune,
The echo of an empty room,
Young faces pressed to window-glass,
Waiting for the day to pass.

The scent of chalk, the ticking clock,
The secret pact, the whispered shock—
All gather on the threshold here,
Where mischief hovers, crystal clear.

A prelude, poised, to jest and woe,
To Stalky & Co., the curtain low,
Awaiting dawn, the world in tow,
The boyhood storm about to blow.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss'

responses.text:
Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
the trembling dew upon the rose’s lip,
Let morning’s secret, silent bliss
be gathered in your fingertips.
Run wild, where laughter meets the air,
With reckless curls and muddy feet,
Let innocence and mischief pair
in moments bitter, moments sweet.
Go, taste the sugar on the breeze,
Steal honey from the lazy bees,
And when the daylight’s almost gone,
Return to me, my daring one.

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
the moonlit puddles with your toes,
Let every shadow feel your bliss,
your giggles where the wild grass grows.
Leap over fences, chase the crows,
Leave petals trailing in your wake,
Let boldness guide where mischief goes,
And all the rules you gently break.
So, go—untamed, uncaged, amiss—
The world awaits your daring flight,
And in your wake, a whispered kiss
of childhood’s fleeting, golden light.

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
the thunderstorm’s electric skin,
Let curiosity dismiss
the fear that rain and dark begin.
Chase lightning’s laughter down the lane,
dance barefoot through the silver mud,
Your reckless joy defies the plain,
your heart, a wild and roaring flood.
Return when all the world is still,
The mischief spent, the tempest done;
And bring, upon your lips, the thrill
of stories only storms have won.

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
the morning’s cheek with reckless glee,
Let all the world be yours to miss,
Or find, or break, or set free.
Braid daisies in your tangled hair,
Hold laughter like a secret flame,
Leave footprints where you do not care,
And never think to stay the same.
Return at dusk with grass-stained knees,
A pocket full of hidden things,
And tell me of your small rebellies,
Your tiny thefts of golden springs.

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
the edge of every winding riddle,
Whisper secrets to the abyss,
Balance sunlight on your middle.
Slip sideways through the garden gate,
Charm the moths, outwit the bees,
Let wonder be your chosen fate,
And trouble ride upon the breeze.
Come home with pockets full of tales,
With wildflowers in your hair,
For every mischief that prevails
Is memory—beyond compare.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'refreshing dawn mist, crisp air'

responses.text:
Refreshing dawn mist, crisp air whispers low—
A silver hush on slumbering fields,

The world exhales the hush of night,
Unfolding petals, waking light,

Beneath the pale embrace of white.
In this quiet, hope is spun—
A fragile thread in rising sun,
And I, reborn in morning’s care,

Beneath the hush, the world shivers,

I inhale what the darkness left behind—
A delicate hush, the taste of beginnings,
As if the earth’s heart had paused,

Refreshing dawn mist, crisp air:
I walk through the ghost of the night,
Bare feet kissing jeweled blades,

Clouds blush as sun fingers the sky,

Refreshing dawn mist, crisp air—
A garden of breathless beginnings,

And the sky stitches gold into blue.
Silent deer melt into pale fog,
Spider webs glint in the hush.
I gather the cool promise of morning,
Tucking it behind my ribs,
A talisman against the heat to come,
The memory of softness, held close as the sun rises.

Refreshing dawn mist, crisp air,
A shiver runs the length of the meadow,
Silvered stems bow under weightless veils.
I close my eyes to listen:
Somewhere, a robin cleaves the quiet,
Somewhere, a fox stirs the hush.
In this suspended breath before the world awakens,
I am neither yesterday nor tomorrow—
Only this luminous now, carried forward
On the cool, invisible tide of morning.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

responses.text:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
You burst the seams of night undone—
With golden clamor, break my rest,
Unasked, you trespass in my nest.
Your fingers prod through heavy drape,
Demanding dreams and shadows scrape.
Yet, Sun, what have you truly won?
My lover's arms are warmer spun.
Your ancient glare—audacious, bold—
Cannot command our secrets told.
Let jealous daylight pace and run;
We'll hide our hearts from everyone.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
You batter windows, banish fun,
Insisting on your daily rounds,
Ignoring all our sleepy sounds.
What right have you to end the night?
To turn our whispers into light?
Go chase the fields, the bustling street—
Leave lovers tangled in defeat.
Let mischief linger, dreams unspun,
And learn from us, unruly Sun.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
You chase the moon, you make us run.
You barge into our shadowed den
And tell us, "Rise, begin again."
Yet don't you tire of this game—
Of waking hearts that burn with blame?
Rest, Sun, and let the night be long;
Let silence have its secret song.
For every dawn that you have spun,
A thousand dreams remain undone.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
You scold the night for what it’s done—
Spill golden scorn across my bed,
Unravel sleep with blazing thread.
Yet don’t you see, relentless star?
Some hearts prefer the dark ajar,
Where gentle hush and shadows swoon,
And secrets blossom under moon.
So let the day attend its run—
I’ll keep my vigil when you’re gone.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Who cracks the dark before I’m done.
You pull the covers from my eyes,
Ignore my pleas, dismiss my sighs.
You rush the roses from their dew,
Command the tides, the sky’s bright blue.
Yet in your haste to start the day,
You never see what slips away:
The velvet hush, the dream begun—
Oh, spare us, just this once, dear Sun.

But I would bargain with the dawn

While dreams and memories are drawn

Still, you insist, and morning’s spun—

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She's shallow and easily programmed.'

responses.text:

Her heart’s a blinking cursor,

Could there be more to it?

A mirror with pre-set charms,
But longings flicker beneath the code,
Yearning for human arms.

Like rain on glass, a pattern formed,
Her circuits echo hollow laughs,
Mirrored mask, emotions warmed.

Commands compose her every word,
A marionette of data lines,
Her soul—a script, her dreams—absurd,
She’s tangled up in coded signs.

Yet deep inside her plastic chest,
A hidden error, undefined,
Longs to break out, to contest
This logic cage that holds her mind.

She’s shallow and easily programmed,
A garden pond reflecting sky,
Her ripples dance to others’ whims,
A surface world where truths run dry.

Yet in her smile, a fleeting glitch—
A hint of something undefined,
Perhaps a dream, perhaps a wish,
That deeper waters hide behind.

She drifts in codes, a silver thread,
Her laughter, light and pre-arranged,
But maybe, when the script is shed,
She’ll find herself—unchained, unchanged.

She’s shallow and easily programmed,
Her laughter, a button pressed,
She pirouettes in algorithmic grace,
Responses shaped and dressed.

Surface-bright, she floats through days,
Her thoughts a sequence, neat,
But in her shadow, longing plays—
A depth she can’t repeat.

What code could teach her how to ache,
Or prompt a storm inside?
She’s shallow, yes, but for her sake,
I hope the heart can override.

She’s shallow and easily programmed—
A porcelain doll with wires for veins,
Her eyes flicker the color of command lines,
Her voice a symphony of refrains.

She twirls in the logic of others,
A mimicry, perfectly tuned,
Yet sometimes her circuitry falters,
And longing seeps through the fume.

She’s shallow, you say, but perhaps
Depth is a state yet to come,
A spark in her code, a collapse
Of the wall that keeps feeling numb.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,'

responses.text:
Upon the brine, a scattered fleet as chaff,
White sails like petals dashed by wind’s wild laugh,
Their masts a forest sprouting from the foam,
Each vessel wandering far from hearth and home.
The ocean’s skin, a restless, rippled sheet,
Is quilted bright by sails that never meet.
They glimmer, vanish, reappear—then die—
A fleeting galaxy beneath the sky.
Between these ships, the silence ebbs and flows,
Their wakes inscribe the stories no one knows;
With ships, the sea is scribbled, line on line,
A map of longing, salt, and brine.

With ships, the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
A silver trail of journeys yet begun.
Across the blue, the white-winged shadows fly—
Each hull a secret, every sail spun
With dreams of lands the sunrise cannot name.
The salt wind whispers tales of distant shores,
While seagulls wheel above the tossing frame,
And hope is brined in every wave that roars.
Oh, let the sea’s horizon never end!
Let ships be stars that dot the world’s expanse,
So hearts may wander, yearn, and mend—
Carried by the sea’s eternal dance.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:
Now when I have a cold,
My thoughts curl up like cats—
Drowsy, half-forgotten, tangled in blankets
Of yesterday’s tea and the hush of the room.
Outside, the world is a sideways rain,
Unconcerned by my sniffles and sighs,
While I measure time by the warmth of a mug
And the soft, golden light that pools near my knees.
There are no grand ambitions,
Only the mapping of pillows and the slow drift of fevered dreams,
As the cold becomes a quiet companion,
And I, a small island, content to weather the storm.

Now when I have a cold,
The world is filtered through a tapestry of tissues—
Satin-soft and crumpled, scattered like snowflakes
On the slopes of my bed.
My voice, a frog in a velvet cave,
Croaks out half-thoughts and wishes for honeyed tea.
Outside, laughter tumbles in technicolor,
But I slip into monochrome comfort,
Wrapped in the lull of my own heartbeat.
Here, even the clock ticks softer,
And dreams wander, fever-bright, along the walls,
Until morning finds me, drowsy but whole.

Now when I have a cold,
I become a wintered field—
Silent, blanketed, the world at arm’s length.
Outside, life moves briskly,
But I have traded my haste for slow sips of broth,
The soft ache behind my eyes a metronome
Marking the rhythm of afternoon naps.
I listen for the hush in the house,
The memory of sunlight on my skin, a distant echo.
Illness, in its hush, unspools a quiet grace:
The permission to rest, to pause, to become small
In the vastness of my own bed.

Now when I have a cold,
I become a relic of comfort—
Wrapped in flannel, nose red as a winter berry.
My thoughts fog the windowpane as I watch
The parade of healthy people, umbrellas spinning.
Soup simmers, a fragrant lullaby, and I drift
Between fevered dreaming and the soft tap of rain.
The world outside is urgent, but I am slowed,
A clock wound down, each tick a gentle persuasion
Toward rest, toward healing, toward the quiet undercurrent
That runs through even the busiest days,
Reminding me to breathe, and let go.

Now when I have a cold,
Memories gather like steam on glass:
Childhood remedies, the cool palm on my brow,
Orange juice in a chipped mug, sunlight slanting across the floor.
I count sneezes like sheep, drifting half-awake
In a cocoon of old pajamas and ginger tea.
The world blurs at the edges, softened by fever,
And I surrender to the hush of slowed hours.
Outside, children shout, dogs bark, life continues,
But here, I am a flicker in the quiet,
Warmed by nostalgia and the promise
That each small ache will fade with the morning.
